Description: Mould-made large amuletic figure in glazed composition, representing the lion-headed goddess Sekhmet; standing, leaning against back pillar, with arms straight down by side; back-pillar inscribed with hieroglyphic inscription identifying the goddess; lion shaped face, with small ears; wearing a tripartite striated wig without headdress, a long dress, with fringe at hem and line across at breast height; modelling details simple but well-executed with fine incisions; glaze gone, bar faint traces of green, overall a dirty sandy reddish brown; core hard medium texture; feet broken off; totally burnt.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes'
Curator's comments: This figure was discovered with many other finds- amongst which a large group of bronze figures- in a house to the south of the town (Petrie 1886, 41-42). Petrie mentioned that a third of the objects was either broken or burnt (Petrie 1886, 41), such as this piece. The cache can be dated around the end of the 5th-beginning of the 4th century BC (Masson 2015). Large amuletic figures of Sekhmet were perhaps produced in Naukratis. A terracotta mould to cast a figure of Sekhmet was discovered in the Scarab Factory (according to Museum records): Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 11.45970. On lion-headed goddess / Sekhmet amulets see: Andrews 1994, 33-34, fig. 10; Herrmann et al. 2010, 39-41 (type 11). For other large amuletic figures of Sekhmet from Naukratis (none from the same mould though): Montreal, Redpath Museum 2410; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.876.
